General Philosophies of Muscle Mass Gain

Sample Diets

Calculate your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) in calories

Bulking Diet:
Calories: TDEE + 500 calories
Protein: 1+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Cutting Diet:
Calories: TDEE - 500 calories
Protein: 1.5+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Maintenance:
Calories: TDEE
Protein: 1.25+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

>>69736847
So far since December 2022 I have been finally putting in true effort in fixing my life since it fell to shit around 2017. 2014-2016 was the only time my life was in order and I really felt even close to being happy. I’m 27 now.
I’m having fuck ups but I keep bouncing back and trying rather than just dwelling for months like I used to. I’m getting consistent with lifting, diet is getting slowly fixed.
I’m nearly off caffeine and holy fuck I can’t believe it took me so long to start quitting it. I was suing over a full gram a day constantly on edge and anxious and unable to focus. Started weaning down, been under 300mg the last few days and there’s a massive difference in my calmness. I’m going to stick to 200-300mg until next week and then cold Turkey from there.
After that I have to quit nicotine which has been a bitch all the times I’ve tried, I will likely use the gum or patches.
Also been meditating and I came to the same realization that let me have my shit in order in 2014-2016: I desire too many things which are out of my reach. Letting go, not giving up but letting go of these desires is making me a lot more calm. I simply don’t care if I get what I want or not so long as I can be healthy and have some form of a life. Ironically, that’s how those desires come into my life.
Side note I added my ex back on Snapchat. Came to the realization I’m only upset because I never really cared about her and feel guilty ending it. But I just don’t care anymore. There will be new and better women. But right now I just focus on getting my health back in order and finding a job.

Will not reply to this post again until tomorrow.

Started translating on Upwork without officially registering for a business. Found bottom-feeding clients there, but I also came into contact there with some agencies that I still to this day continue working with.

All of the above in 2018. Went slow for two years, then met a domestic client (applied for a job interview, told them that I also offer translation services on a freelance basis, and now this client leaves me 50k EUR per year).

Registered for a business in January 2020. Fast forward to today, I have a full time in-house translator as an employee and on my way to complete my website and start officially as an agency (already work as an agency, as I subcontract 90% of work I undertake).

I wrote the above to give you some context. Now, regarding you:
Register yourself in Upwork and Proz.
Register to huge LSPs like Transperfect, Lionbridge & Welocalize.
Find, via Google maps, local agencies that might be looking for a translator. Even an in-house position, although not worthy money-wise, will leave you with a lot of experience.
Fake it till you make it. If you get offered a project and they ask you if you have relevant experience, if you trust that you know the subject (e.g., gaming/fitness), just say that you do have some, and if they ask for work samples, say that all your work is NDA-protected.
Also, when taking tests, be VERY FUCKING CAREFUL, because a 200-word test will either give you the chance of your life or block you from it.
Peace.

rotator cuff. don't say "but it's my bicep, not my shoulder", your rotator cuff extends partway down your arm

>>69740061
The thing with "Shitwork", which is shit, I agree, is that it is maybe the only place where you will get the chance to undertake work without credentials, simply because the people who offer work are looking to complete an one-time thing or are cheap fucks, or usually both.

ProZ is probably the most reputable site out there, being online since like 2000. Many agencies, during the application process, ask for your ProZ profile. However, I believe that in the next few years, LinkedIn will surpass them all, as I see more and more LinkedIn translation job posting, as well as many translation companies HR managers visiting my LinkedIn profile.

Also, if you want regular work, and you are not some kind of reputable individual translator, you will be working with agencies.

Forget, I repeat, FORGET, offering "easy" and "techie" payment solutions like bitcoin. 99.99% of agencies will want a legal invoice from you, so they can deduct your fees from their tax profits. This is industry standard, and pretty much applies to most service-based industries. Offering to be paid in Bitcoin only makes you look like some scammy, inexperienced and unprofessional kid.

And yes, the client usually sets the rules for that. Most US-based agencies work with Payoneer & PayPal, while European ones tend to prefer Bank Account Numbers (IBAN). Something like Transferwise is also possible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69724426
Finasteride has zero lasting side effects, even in people who get temporary sides like ED while they're taking it, they disappear a few weeks to months after they stop. So you have literally nothing to lose by trying fin. If it works, you'll be very glad you started taking it. If you are among the few people who get side effects, you can just stop taking it and that's it. You're no worse off than before.

I started taking it five years ago when I noticed the first signs of balding (I had already researched the topic beforehand because I knew I would get bald early due to my genetics) and I think it was one of the best decisions of my life. I have almost perfect hair while all my male relatives were already almost completely bald at my age.

>>69733123
>this thread again
The newest egg "controversy" is based on a 2017 study that you can read here:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5460631/

They weren't examining dietary eggs, they were testing supplemental choline and blood levels of TMAO, a pro-thrombotic (blood clotting factor) that gut bacteria can produce when digesting choline.

It's worth noting that the research predates Covid-19, so it's very interesting than it has only now been chosen to be pushed by clickbait tabloid media.

The study gave volunteers 450mg of choline split into two doses per day. This is the equivalent of around 4 eggs worth of choline.

It's also important to note that as with any study examining supplemental nutrients, its results cannot be extrapolated to normal dietary consumption of the same nutrient. Gut-food interactions are incredibly complex.

In fact, a 2021 randomized trial found exactly that: Supplemental choline raised blood levels of TMAO, but the equivalent dose of choline from eating eggs did NOT raise blood levels of TMAO
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33872583/

>Participants' plasma TMAO levels increased significantly in all 3 intervention arms containing choline bitartrate (all P < .0001), but daily ingestion of 4 large eggs (P = .28) or phosphatidylcholine supplements (P = .27) failed to increase plasma TMAO levels. Platelet reactivity also significantly increased in the 3 intervention arms containing choline bitartrate (all P < .01), but not with eggs (P = .10) or phosphatidylcholine supplements (P = .79).
>Despite high choline content in egg yolks, healthy participants consuming 4 eggs daily showed no significant increase in TMAO or platelet reactivity. However, choline bitartrate supplements providing comparable total choline raised both TMAO and platelet reactivity, demonstrating that the form and source of dietary choline differentially contributes to systemic TMAO levels and platelet responsiveness.

>Because there are different types of cholesterol.
There are different carrier lipoproteins, actually. There is only one "cholesterol", which is a substrate for many other chemicals in the body, including most steroid hormones.
HDL, LDL, VLDL etc are all proteins which carry cholesterol (and other lipids) around the body. They are only colloquially called "good cholesterol" and "bad cholesterol".

>>69741031
tldr:
>find maintence calories
(the calories to maintain your current weight)
>eat 500-1000calories under this
(you can eat more, but there will be more negative side effects, I.E libido drops, mood decreases, test goes down, strength goes down, less active, cravings increase, "fullness" decreases, etc. I personally do more than recommended, but I know my way around the block)


protein needs are roughly 1.8-2.4g /kg of LBM, but to spare you autism, and just to be sure you're in taking adequate protein, and lets not forget it increases Satiety, just eat as much as you're goal body weight (or height in centimeters)

teckehekcnically, you should be eating 30% of your gBW in Fat, but in reality all you "need" is 1.6-3.0g of EPA/DHA (fishoils) and-or no less then 15-30grams of fat.

there are physiological adaptions to your psychological mind, every single person ever recorded to have an eating disorder has a history of dieting, do not even attempt to diet unless you are sure you want to do it. ALSO, the end of the diet is harder than the start, when you begin to eat at your new maintenance (lower than previous) you will be fucking ravenous (at least I was), this goes away.
^
to note this, I had to do a super cut (I was over 400 pounds) and I can't feel emotions that much anymore, not much libido, and a few more things, I also don't really get full/hungry, it's slowly coming back, but this will take probably 6-18 MONTHS before it normalizes, even with the 8 months I've already taken. MOST people don't have this bad of a time with it, but I got the shit end of the stick I guess. good luck

also inb4 what to eat, literally anything as long as it fits your macros/calories, wholefoods/micronutrient dense foods are more filling and may cause you not to binge as easily as say a chocolate bar, but I eat protein powder covered popcorn, homemade tacos, ice cream sandwhiches, etc, daily. you just have to be smart and make it yourself.

Lies. I'm at a stay at home dad. I manage a 2400sqft house, handle all the finances and shopping, 3 kids, 3 dogs, 2 lizards. It takes 8 hours of week to cook, 1 hour a day to keep the house clean, 1 hour of tending to the kids (for tasks that aren't necessarily enjoyable), and one shopping trip per week. The only thing I could percieve as being stressful is that you're on-call 24 hours a day for if a dog vomits on the rug, or if kids get sick. You are expected to handle anything that comes up, day or night. That means you can't settle into an activity undisturbed for hours on the end. You can't expect to get a full 8 hours of sleep per day. You can't truly relax under your normal schedule. You have to make special arrangements if you want to be left alone for a few hours. That is the primary difference. There is no real vacation to be had until the kids get older. And that's just an inconvenience at worst. It's a small price to pay.

>>69732623
That's pretty much spot on. There is a lot of data collected from a large variety of sellers all over (if for instance we're looking at the NY Times best seller list, which is the most popular in the US, it is data from all over the US). However, there's a lot of factors:
1) Yes, it is absolutely tallied every week, thus new winners are awarded every week.
2) While there are three major categories, there are shit tons of subcategories, so literally dozens can be awarded best seller every single week.
3) It is not even a measure of who sold the most that week in that category: there are simple minimums. For big categories I believe it's 10,000 sold in a single week. For smaller it could be 7500 or 5000.
4) Sales are not cumulative, so it has to be 5-10k in a single week, but that also means a book that sells 2k every week for 52 weeks straight will waaaay outsell a book that has a big media push and sells 20k in one week then 10k second week, then practically nothing forever after, but only the latter will have the best seller award.

And just like movies, publishers know when other books are being published, even by other publishers, so they can time certain books to be released during lulls to boost relative visibility. Along with a halfway decent advertising campaign, it's rather easy to get on the best seller list, and you only need to get on it for one week to be able to forever parade it on the cover.

The hardest part is actually convincing the publisher to invest that kind of advertisement push on your book.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69721634
The tricep contracts (pulls itself) to push two bones away from each other (humerous away from forearm).
When the lat contracts it pulls two bones together, your humerous to your ribs/thorax.
These are not arbitrary.
When your pec contracts it pushes your humerous away from your ribs/thorax/clavicle.
When your bicep contracts it pulls closer your humerous and forearm.
Quad contracts it pushes away your thigh bone from your shin.
Do you understand yet?
It is about moving a bone closer or further away across the joint.
When you pull down you are pulling the humerous all the way from the top (180 degrees) to the bottom (0 degrees)

>>69721428
You are playing stupid semantic games that are not helpful for understanding the exercises. Everybody knows that "push" simply refers to the action of the muscles that move the hands farther away from your center of mass (i.e. chest/shoulders/tris) and that "pull" simply refers to the action of the muscles that move the hands closer to your center of mass (i.e. back and bis). The categorical distinction is useful because it groups movements together that have meaningful things in common from a functional and training standpoint.

For example - it is USEFUL to say that you should not push down from a pullup/chinup because, colloquially and intuitively, this would suggest that one should engage the chest and shoulders ("pushing" muscles) and relax the back ("pulling" muscles) to accelerate downward. This would produce a sub-optimal exercise, because muscles respond really well to being forced to lengthen under tension (i.e., controlled descent) rather than from only having to contract when shortening.

Congratulations, you've discovered the fact that jargon and terminology is technically arbitrary and you could technically get together with friends and conduct an entire cogent fitness discussion while speaking entirely in words like zorp and blipbloop if you damn well felt like it. Nobody cares. The terminology that's actually in use is perfectly functional and you contribute nothing by being a nitpicky fag about it.

>>69727912
Quick question first. Are you only lifting twice per week or is this done more frequently?
>>69727962
>Day 1
I know this will sound weird but you should move the row to this day. The upper back can get worked every day if it's biasing different muscles in the back each time. You should space out your presses with something unrelated in between. I'd also swap the flies with dips and add an overhead extension and lateral raise
>Day 2
You only need 1 hip hinge. Both good mornings and deadlifts are good lifts so either would be fine to keep. Move the hip hinge to the beginning of the day and put the pullups right after to decompress your spine. Move the neck work over here too. The push day is full enough that you could put neck here and be okay
>Day 3
No need for the hip thrust with your hip hinge being on the pull day. Double the calf volume. No other changes needed
>Other considerations
Run this as a Pull, Push, Legs instead. It's the best order for this split. I'd schedule it as PPLx or PPLxx. Doing PPLPPLx or PPL to infinity is proven to be retarded and zaps your recovery. Also superset your isolations wherever you can without them interfering with one another. It'll save a lot of time. Not a bad program for your first try bro

>>69727912
Do this instead
>Day 1
Deadlift 4x3-6
Pulldowns 4x8-12
Bulgarian Split Squats 3x10-15
SUPERSET x3
Facepull 10-15
Curl of Choice 10-15
>Day 2
Bench Press 4x6-10
Bent Over Row 3x8-12
OHP 3x8-12
SUPERSET x3
Overhead Extension 10-15
Dumbbell Lateral Raise 10-15
>Why
You're missing a quad dominant movement so it's good to add that to the routine. Split squats are one of the best and you'll get a lot out of them without your deadlift impacting their performance too much as long as there's something in between them. Same with your presses. Always put a row or pullup in between your presses. You can work the back every day as long as you bias different muscles of the upper back each day. I traded the pushdown for the overhead extension because your medial and lateral heads are going to grow like crazy while the long head stays small if you're doing pushdowns while doing all that pressing. There's nothing for the long head other than a little stimulation from OHP, but it's not enough. Supersets are also highly recommended for all your isolations to save time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69729618
You're all over the place with this program. I'll move some stuff around for you while doing my best to keep the spirit of the program, but it's not optimal
>Push 1
Bring the reps down on bench to 3x6-10, move the incline to after bench for 3x8-12, and move the OHP to after incline for 3x10-15. Do a giantset for the isolations for 3x10-15 each and trade the pushdown for an overhead extension this day.
>Push 2
Opposite order as day 1 with the same sets and rep pattern. OHP, then incline, then add dips or dumbbell bench. Giantset isolations and trade the overhead extension for tricep pushdowns.
>Pull 1
Barbell Rows for 3x10-15. They do well with high reps. Swap the lat pulldown and the pullup. Swap face pulls for reverse pec dec. Move hammer curls down and superset with reverse pec dec.
>Pull 2
Copy Pull 1 and change the variations while keeping the idea the same. Barbell rows are now Yates rows, pullups are now chinups, chest supported row is now the cable row, and the rear delt isolation is now skiers.
>Legs
Move the RDL to right after squats, superset lunges and calf raises, then superset curls and extensions.

>>69737748

>>69737801
>neck curls
It'll grow your neck flexors. Especially the sternocleidomastoid (picrel) so you'll have a big neck from the front and sides. Add in neck side curls and avoid neck extensions. Neck extensions put a lot of pressure on the atlas and axis of the spine, which is where your spine connects to your skull, and it causes a lot of injuries. To train the neck extensors tilt your head back while doing trap work. It's a lot safer and will get you even better results for that area. Also use more of a pumping, pulsing technique for the neck when it's weighted. The neck has the same level of mobility as the shoulder joint but without the muscular structure to support heavy loads with a lot of range of motion. Passively it can go through all of it's ROM but actively using it is a bad idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69741095
You're better off just lifting to find out what you can personally can lift in that moment. The differences in muscle insertions, limb lengths and proportions, muscle belly size, etc is too much to figure out before you lift
>>69741219
Higher reps and lower weight for sure. Also do lots of wrist stretching throughout the day and add forearm extensor work to your program.
>EZ Bar curls
It could be the top half of the rep, or maybe the top 3/4, or wherever your body starts to have issues. You might have to cut off part of the top of the ROM even. When you take it slow, watch your body in the mirror, and pay close attention to how different joints feel at different parts of the movement, you'll be able to find your effective range of motion. If you're trying to build muscle, things like always having full ROM aren't necessary. That mentality comes from strength athletes who needed to regulate form for competitions. If you watch seasoned bodybuilders train it's very rare that you see them do full ROM on almost anything for a reason. You're trying to stimulate the muscle; not practice for a competitive lift. Once I started using that mentality and paying attention to my body for each exercise to see where I get the most simulation with the least strain on my joints my injury rate went to nearly 0 per year while making faster gains than I had made in any of my prior years

If you treat it like a hormonal issue, as it is, and not an energy balance issue, which it isn't, you can cut out enough(ALL) carbohydrates to allow yourself to consume enough protein to keep your muscle and continue working out. The issue most beginner keto weightlifters have is that they're used to the immediate and explosive energy that carbohydrates allow them, so they never allow themselves the adjustment period of entering fat adaptation (primary metabolic state or ketogenesis) and consume disgusting amounts of honey or other sweets to retain the explosive energy.
If you're consuming carbs, you can't consume protein or you risk dropping out of the primary metabolic state. Your glycogen stores will fill up steadily, but slower, until your body fully adjusts to the primary metabolic state, which could take weeks, so you'll be at 80%, but suffer no muscle loss.

Ignore my advice and go for energy balance retardation(CICO) and suffer the losses.

>>69741324

If ur at the point of self harm or suicide, please seek treatment. These steps can help with minor depression but severe depression requires some kind of therapy.

Number of things help with depression.
Personal experience has been hitting the gym. Make it a point to get there and spend at least 5 min doing an exercise. Jogging, running or biking will help too. Weightlifting with a simple program will also help you to stick to training and tracking your workout to see progress.

Have also noted that complimenting people helps me and helps others. Doesn’t matter the sex. Male or female, compliment something they are wearing or a style they are doing. Making other people’s day can boost both parties happiness. Also helping people.
Homeless person, get em something to eat. Old lady, help with whatever they are doing to assist within reason.
There are also things like hobbies to get into to help focus ur mind and also improve your self view.
Think about ur day and highlighting the positives will also help improve things.

Learning to cook and cooking for others will also improve health and moods.

There are a lot of little things you can do to fight back depression.

>>69743804
You're either lying about the amount of your caloric deficit, not lying but ignorant to the true caloric value of what you're consuming, or consuming the correct number of calories but you're one of the types of people who if you get enough protein can build muscle while in a slight deficit.

I'm the last group. When I was losing weight a while back I started lifting pretty hard in the gym around 230 lbs. I stagnated for months on end, but I got noticeably bigger and better muscle definition in the mirror and my lifts got dramatically heavier. During that same span of time, the waist on my pants got several inches smaller as well.

From what I could deduce, I had built roughly the equivalent weight in muscle that I had been losing in fat. Eventually that slowed down because I hit a wall for my muscle gains but switched over to essentially lifting maintenance reps in the window of 10-15 per set and 3-4 sets per exercise and increasing my caloric deficit. I drank a fuckload of water, added in cardio, my food intake was very heavy in protein and fiber, and the weight loss continued faster than before. I lost some off my PR that I had to work back to later.

Regardless of the reason, decide now what it is you're doing. Are you getting strong as fuck, or are you losing fat. Doing both at the same time (if that's even what you're doing) won't last forever. Pick which thing is more important to you and go all in on it until you've hit your goal and then tackle the other thing. Either get as strong as you want to get and then cut really hard, or cut really hard right now and then focus on going through a bulk cycle afterwards.

>>69742753
Firstly if you look like the OP pic you need to eat more, especially if you want to put on muscle.
Here's a simplified picture of things: The main two muscles in your arm are the bicep and tricep. You work the tricep whenever you open your arm in a pushing motion, for example with bench press or dips. You work the bicep when you close your arm in a pulling motion, for example with chinups or bicep curls.
You should work out your whole body rather than just focus on your arms though. Bench press is good, and it's hard for girls to put on much size in the pecs anyway so don't worry about that.
Google "women's upper body gym routine" and look through a few. Try them out and steal the parts you like.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dream edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For fatties who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69733611
i struggled with staying on keto in the past I started doing One Meal A Day with a slightly higher carb limit. I am convinced that keto helped me control my hunger which made OMAD a possibility. I basically reverse engineered the Atkins diet (atkins recommends low carb for 6mo- year and some level of reintroduction of carbs after that) but added Omad which helps keep insulin well regulated and keeps you off of the glycemic roller coaster.
I sleep better, I work better and my wife claims I fuck better.
Whole foods where possible.
No grains of any kind. Period.
Just about any kind of meat is great.
Salads with eggs or chicken.
Steamed/boiled veggies with variety in mind.
I have a small-medium serving of either potato or sweet potato with my meal, this helps get to the calories I need along with cheese and butter where applicable.
My meals range from 1400-1800 calories depending on carbs. I do sometimes accidentally go a few days without carbs and you can really tell in both good and bad ways when you are deeper in ketosis.
cook at home you will realize how much time you used to waste eating multiple times a day. I make a dozen boiled eggs at a time refrigerate use when you can. Get some mrs dash spice mix, i really like the original but theres a lot of varieties. Goes on everything, zero cal, and simple. You could probably make your own mix cheaper/ better but ease is your friend.
I want to reiterate
>ease is your friend
If I need a dessert, I get plain yogurt, nuts and fruit. Ive splurged before and had icecream but that is very infrequent and cannot be recommended.
The results speak for themselves, im down 55 lbs went from obesity 3 to obesity 1 in 6mo, bloodwork is stabilizing blood sugar went from iffy to perfect, saw a slight reduction in non-alcoholic fatty live disease but still have some work to do. now im working on adding muscle.
Ive failed a lot getting to this point, the less you beat yourself up the better

unironically take dexamphetamine/adderall

No, that's not a joke. I was a fat fuck, too, in my late teens to really 20s. Since I couldn't focus anymore and desperately needed to study for my bar exam, my doctor prescribed me Adderall against ADHD (which was obviously a wrong diagnosis as I only couldn't concentrate because being a lardass hurt my sleep quality and made my T levels drop to next to zero).
The diagnosis was wrong, but the medication was right. That stuff made me completely forget any feeling of hunger because it's a powerful appetite suppressant, I would go entire days without eating without even realizing (only bad thing was that it affected my thirst as well, so I had to force myself to drink enough water). I got to normal weight within a year or so and also started lifting weights.

Then, I realized that I didn't even need the medication anymore because my overall brain chemistry had returned to healthy levels (no sugar + fat addiction anymore, sufficient T levels, good quality of sleep). I could focus again without any issue and had no cravings for food anymore. So I just stopped taking the pills regularly (I still took them on occasion when I had to study very intensely for a specific exam, I only ceased taking them altogether about a year ago) and I've maintained a healthy weight ever since (approximately five years now).

Adderall/dexamphetamine is an amazing drug to overcome an addiction - which obesity is, really, it's nothing but a food addiction. If your problem is cravings, you should really try it.

Any exercise helps with insulin resistance but weight loss helps more. This damages the "Just run" idea: my high school did the swimming unit for gym class and they taught us breathing techniques to help us swim efficiently:
-embrace that your face is almost always going to be in the water
-exhale completely underwater through nose
-do that quick mouth intake during the stroke, adapt it to your rhythm.
This stuff is also not intuitive, but since there was active guidance - and also guidance on swim form and using legs and all that - I and most of us were quickly swimming competently.

We received no coaching regarding running. Meanwhile, few people in the general public enjoy running. So you can say "just run" because you already know how, but that doesn't help people like me who have benefitted massively from roonthread. posts.name: Anonymous

>>69733312
That is normal. With intense exertion during exercise, some excess hemoglobin released from the blood in the lungs and is transported through the bronchi to the mouth. Once in our mouths, the iron molecules in that hemoglobin come in contact with the tastebuds on the tongue.

Zone 1 is basically a walk in the park, Zone 2 is a more strenuous walk or an easy jog. Zone 3 is where it starts to feel like work, but it isn't really hurting bad yet. Zone 4-5 is pain town.

I'd be surprised if anyone has numbers of this exact question. I'm making the following assumptions.
> Male
> Aged 18 - 30
> Already physically active most days (and has been for some time) through work or hobby etc even if it isn't "training".
> Never smoked habitually
> BMI around 22 or lower
> Diet not a total train wreck
> Doesn't drink heavily or at least not frequently
> No chronic health conditions that would significantly affect performance

If you tick these boxes then I'd say it's more likely than not that you could hit a sub 20 5k within a few months at most assuming you set it as a goal and assuming we're talking about running the distance on a track or some other flat surface.

>You could of course run a half marathon, but I doubt that'll increase your 5k times.
It would, dramatically. Assuming you built up to the distance gradually.
There's a lot of ways you could do 30mpw.
Something like
> 10 mile slow long run
> Interval session, 5x 1k repeated + 2 miles slow warmup + cool down
> 4 mile tempo run
> 2x 5 mile easy runs

That gets you to about 29mpw with 5 runs. That would probably get most young dudes to sub 20 fairly quick, assuming the stipulations I outlined before.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69741435
At this point you're creating a mythical ideal beginning runner.
Getting up to 30 miles and back to back runs multiple times a week takes time.
learning warm up and recovery takes time.
learning to control your pace takes time.
So yes, someone with your demographics on a good fast 5k program probably could hit sub 20 in a few months with good drive.
But if a complete beginner runner tries (even if they're already in good shape), they'll probably hurt themselves.
Also I looked at some local races, and generally it's 1-10 people out of 40-200 finishing under 20 (most were under 20 or over 30 as well).
Under 20 isn't very impressive for a competitive runner, but it makes you an accomplished hobbyist.

This post is correct, but it seems to be inferring an illogical conclusion.
In bygone eras, almost everyone was regularly dancing, playing physical games or sports, engaged in manual labour, walked almost everywhere because transport was expensive or non-existent, and food was comparatively scarce compared to the modern age.
Because of this, recreational exercise was completely unnecessary. It is not axiomatic, therefore, that we shouldn't be exercising. Rather, it is axiomatic that we therefore must exercise recreationally in order to offset our sedentary lifestyles and virtually unlimited food.
For millions of years, everyone hunted or grew their own food through exhausting physical exertion, and struggled to get enough food to survive, let alone become fat.

The sign is a subtle joke. The shop is called "Sneed's Feed & Seed", where feed and seed both end in the sound "-eed", thus rhyming with the name of the owner, Sneed. The sign says that the shop was "Formerly Chuck's", implying that the two words beginning with "F" and "S" would have ended with "-uck", rhyming with "Chuck". So, when Chuck owned the shop, it would have been called "Chuck's Fuck and Suck".

posts.name: Anonymous

>movement is medicine, if you have pain in a tendon/joint you can't just let it rest, you need to get lots and lots of bloodflow to it. that being said don't put tons of load on it either as that will just make things worse
>more people should do piriformis work, everything involving the hip feels nicer after. weighted incline (flat once you progress enough) pigeon good mornings are my go-to
>everyone should have a squat-pattern exercise with maximal knee bend somewhere in their program for knee health and VMO development. doesn't necessarily have to be a barbell squat though
>larsen press is better than bench press for pec hypertrophy in most cases
>you should spend as much time as possible in a surplus, as you're playing offense in a surplus and defense in a deficit. therefore, bulks should be 1 year long at minimum, preferably 1.5-2 years, while cuts can be much faster.
>permabulking is also an option if you have a small appetite as the periods where you slack on your diet will work as a minicut, meaning that in some cases you can literally bulk for 5 years straight if you're comfortable being at a slightly higher bodyfat
>recomping does work, but the tradeoff is that it is much slower than bulk/cut cycles. it is only useful for novices who are not too skinny or too fat, and for advanced lifters that need a period of stability for whatever reason, as this is the main benefit of a recomp
>while tracking calories is fine, you can bulk and cut without tracking calories by closely monitoring your weight and altering your intention of how much food you need to consume depending on whether you're bulking/cutting too fast, too slowly, or at just the right rate. this won't work for everyone though

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>static rep ranges like 3x10 are not particularly good for hypertrophy because of sandbagging, rep ranges like 3x8-12 are much better. however, the fewer sets you do, the less flawed static rep ranges are, for example there is no sandbagging at all with 1x5, but 5x5 will result in a lot of sandbagging
>on exercises where adding reps is extremely hard but adding small amounts of weight is easy, static rep pyramids are also better than static rep ranges. instead of 3x8 for example, you would do 9/8/7 reps
>training the tibialis anterior and the soleus can help fix knee/shin pain from high impact activities; the soleus is also important for achilles tendon health
>once you're out of the novice stage, you should write your own program instead of continuing to use cookie-cutter programs as programming for yourself will account for your individual differences and preferences much better. though you could simply make changes to the novice program you were running over time, so that it evolves with you as your training progresses
>when training for strength, you want to get the most advantageous leverages to lift the most amount of weight possible. when training for hypertrophy, you want to get the most disadvantageous leverages to lift the least amount of weight possible

>if you want free work for your upper traps, after finishing a set of any exercise that involves holding a barbell/dumbbells in your hands, do shrugs to failure. if the weight is too heavy (deadlifts, rackpulls), hold it at lockout instead. straps are necessary for this, obviously

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69741717
>All bilateral work is ego lifting.
Disagree, even ignoring time constraints this knocks out so many really good exercises (most barbell movements, most ring movements, most machines, most calisthenics movements, etc) that it really isn't worth it
>If you don't do unilateral exercises mainly then you have muscle imbalances.
Humans are innately imbalanced but even ignoring this if you aren't addressing muscle imbalances not just between each muscle pair but also between antagonists (quads/hams) and joints (hips/knees/ankles) then it's kind of a fruitless effort IMO
>Whey and Casein are garbage supplements.
>Gelatin and Collagen are better but still garbage.
>Glycine is the only protein supplement you want and need.
Ambivalent because I don't really have any strong opinions about supplements other than the fact that they aren't necessary for the vast majority of people
>Working your mid and lower pecs is gay.
Avoiding a specific muscle because training it is gay somehow is gay in of itself IMO but that's just me. Also rip dip chads
>Shoulders, arms, back, and posterior chain are the only muscles that matter.
As a bodybuilder every muscle matters, if you're an athlete then the muscles that contribute to being better at your sport are the ones that matter. That being said posterior chain is fairly underrated among the general population, however a lot of people became contrarians and started neglecting their quads in favor of the posterior chain which isn't any better desu.
>Direct ab work, pec work, quads work, and traps work will ruin your physique.
Abs/pecs are entirely subjective, and as for quads I personally think that small quads look disgusting but again it's subjective. Ridiculously large upper traps can ruin your physique in some cases but generally this is only an issue with roiders due to androgen sensitivity and all that.
